hints.text: Remember that Java is a strongly typed language. You need to specify the data type when declaring a variable.
To declare an integer variable, use the `int` keyword. For example: `int myVariable = 10;`.
The `System.out.println()` method is used to print output to the console. You can concatenate strings and variables using the `+` operator.

metadata.title: Valid Variable Declaration
metadata.description: Identify the correct syntax for declaring a variable in Java.

props.title: Task 2: Identify Correct Syntax
props.question: Which of the following is a valid way to declare and initialize an integer variable named `count` with the value `100` in Java?

metadata.title: Feedback for Task 2
metadata.description: Shows correctness, explanation, and next steps for the multiple-choice question.

props.title: Correct!
props.message: You correctly identified the valid variable declaration syntax.
props.explanation: In Java, you specify the data type (e.g., `int`) before the variable name, followed by an assignment operator (`=`) and the value, ending with a semicolon. `int count = 100;` follows this rule.
nextSteps: Practice declaring variables with other data types like `double` or `String`.
